I obviously agree with abolishing any crimes related to consensual sex, with the exception that consent doesn't make statutory rape all right etc.
 
 I have problems abolishing all "victimless" crimes such as drug use. I do think that large prison sentences for simple possession are a detriment that does nothing but assure later crime and overfill our prisons. At the same time, victimless crimes often lead to others. A person on a cocaine binge can get violent and, of course, there is the sterotypical crack addict who mugs people to be able to pay his dealer.
 
 It comes down to what we want our criminal system to be. If we wish the justice system to punish those who commit crimes than we can just wait for the violent crimes resulting from drug use etc. and imprison them for that. If our justice system is designed to help prevent such crimes, then laws that deter destructive behavior are in order.
 
 These laws, however, should be more on the order of fines or community service and thus act more like a sin tax than a criminal law. If you call for a complete end to all crimes that the law declares "victimless" you run a lot of risks.
 
 For example, there was a court case that found computer generated child pornography, that is, an actual minor was not involved, legal. Owning or distributing CG child pornography, in that sense, is a victimless crime.
 
 It's a tenuous balance and like most things in life, the correct answer lies somewhere in the middle.

 With regards to law, perhaps this brings us to a more fundamental question about what the purpose of law is. Is it punitive in nature (that is, does it exist simply to punish offenders?) or is it more preventative (it exists to stop future offenders before they begin)? 
 
 I will argue that the reason for the so called "victimless crimes" is often more preventative in nature. While one cannot blanketly say "all people who use drugs are addicts", it is a fair thing to say that most street drugs available today will not enhance one's life, will more than likely lead to addiction, will often have lasting effects on both the person's health as well as their relationships with family and friends, and (currently) will also finance criminal operations that manufacture or produce the illegal drugs. I will also venture (not knowing any stats) that most people that begin illegal drug use are teenagers, or at least a huge portion, and teenagers often seem to think they are invincible, and often lack an ability to grasp the gravity of an addiction (whereas, say, a 25 year old who knows how hard it is to quit smoking might understand addiction a bit better).
